questions.question_text_1: Read the following passage and answer the given subquestions  I am a rather elderly man. The nature of my avocations for the last thirty years has brought me into more than ordinary contact with what would seem an interesting and somewhat singular set of men, of whom as yet nothing that I know of has ever been written:—I mean the law-copyists or scriveners. I have known very many of them, professionally and privately, and if I pleased, could relate diverse histories, at which good-natured gentlemen might smile, and sentimental souls might weep. But I waive the biographies of all other scriveners for a few passages in the life of Bartleby, who was a scrivener of the strangest I ever saw or heard of. While of other law-copyists I might write the complete life, of Bartleby  nothing of that sort can be done. I believe that no materials exist for a full and satisfactory biography of this man. It is an irreparable loss to literature. Bartleby was one of those beings of whom nothing is ascertainable, except from the original sources, and in his case those are very small. What my own astonished eyes saw of Bartleby, that is all I know of him, except, indeed, one vague report which will appear in the sequel.  Ere introducing the scrivener, as he first appeared to me, it is fit I make some mention of myself, my employées, my business, my chambers, and general surroundings; because some such description is indispensable to an adequate understanding of the chief character about to be presented.  Imprimis: I am a man who, from his youth upwards, has been filled with a profound conviction that the easiest way of life is the best. Hence, though I belong to a profession proverbially energetic and nervous, even to turbulence, at times, yet nothing of that sort have I ever suffered to invade my peace. I am one of those unambitious lawyers who never addresses a jury, or in any way draws down public applause; but in the cool tranquility of a snug retreat, do a snug business among rich men’s bonds and mortgages and title-deeds. All who know me, consider me an eminently safe man. The late John Jacob Astor, a personage little given to poetic enthusiasm, had no hesitation in pronouncing my first grand point to be prudence; my next, method. I do not speak it in vanity, but simply record the fact, that I was not unemployed in my profession by the late John Jacob Astor; a name which, I admit, I love to repeat, for it hath a rounded and orbicular sound to it, and rings like unto bullion. I will freely add, that I was not insensible to the late John Jacob Astor’s good opinion.       Source: Bartleby, the Scrivener - Herman Melville

questions.question_text_1: Read the following exchange between a student and a professor and answer the given subquestions:    Abeer: Hi, Professor Sriram. My name is Abeer. Prof. Sriram: Hi, Abeer. How can I help you?  Abeer: I was told that you place students in internships for various university programs. Prof. Sriram: Yes.  Abeer: Well, I am interested in the internship at the university art museum… what responsibilities interns have, what qualifications they need to have... Prof. Sriram: Sorry, those positions are all filled for this year...  Abeer: Oh! But I just saw the announcement on the museum website this morning. Prof. Sriram: Unfortunately, the website is out of date.  Abeer: I want to do museum work after I graduate, and the job experience would look great on my résumé. Plus it's the only paid internship on campus. Prof. Sriram: I understand. However, there are some other ways to get some work experience, even if it's not exactly what you want. For instance, the library is looking for student volunteers.  Abeer: The library? But... Prof. Sriram: Well, they're planning an exhibition of photographs documenting the history of the university. And they're looking for student volunteers to help go through the archives and select images that'll show how the university's changed over the last hundred years.  Abeer: Hmm... Prof. Sriram: Now that's only a four-week project, I think. And, of course, it's unpaid.  Abeer: But it would be something to put on my résumé... Prof. Sriram: Exactly. Why don't you read the job description—it's posted on the library's website. If you're interested, let me know, and I'll put in a good word for you with Geeta Raj. She's the library's exhibitions director and will be interviewing applicants.  Abeer: OK, I'll do that right away.

questions.question_text_1: Fill in the blanks with correct expressions of numbers/values/quantity and answer the given subquestions.   Global economic activity is experiencing a broad-based and sharper-than-expected slowdown, with inflation (1) _____________________ than seen in several decades. The cost-of-living crisis, tightening financial conditions in most regions, Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, and the lingering COVID-19 pandemic all weigh heavily on the outlook. Global growth is forecast to slow from 6.0 percent in 2021 to 3.2 (2)______________________ in 2022 and 2.7 percent in 2023. This is the weakest growth profile since 2001 except for the global financial crisis and the (3) _______________________ phase of the COVID-19 pandemic. Global inflation is forecast to rise from 4.7 percent in 2021 to 8.8 percent in 2022 but to decline to (4) ______________________________ 6.5 percent in 2023 and to (5) ______________________ 4.1 percent by 2024. Monetary policy should stay the course to restore price stability, and fiscal policy should aim to alleviate the cost-of-living pressures while maintaining a sufficiently tight stance aligned with monetary policy.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, and principles** for the **"English 2" (Semester 2, Foundation Level)** exam, based on the provided question paper.
The exam tests **comprehension, grammar, vocabulary, syntax, semantics, and communication skills** in English.
No equations are involved (as this is a language-focused subject), but rules, definitions, and linguistic structures are critical.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Reading Comprehension**
   - **Key Skills**:
     - Identifying the **main idea**, **tone**, and **purpose** of a passage.
     - Inferring **implicit meanings** (e.g., why the speaker avoids writing about other scriveners in *Bartleby, the Scrivener*).
     - Recognizing **literary devices** (e.g., irony, metaphor, understatement).
     - Answering **fact-based** and **inference-based** questions.
   - **Example Passage**: *Bartleby, the Scrivener* by Herman Melville (focus on **character analysis**, **narrator’s perspective**, and **themes of isolation**).
   - **Vocabulary in Context**:
     - Synonyms/antonyms (e.g., *avocation* = hobby, *tranquility* ≠ chaotic).
     - Word stress and syllables (e.g., *destiny* → **DES-ti-ny** [stress on 1st syllable]).

---

### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
#### **A. Sentence Structure**
   - **Simple/Compound/Complex Sentences**:
     - *Rohan resigned and joined a new company.* → **Compound sentence** (two independent clauses).
   - **Clauses**:
     - **Relative/Adjectival Clauses** (modify nouns):
       - *Reena, **who developed the algorithm**, was honored.* → *"who developed the algorithm"* is the adjectival clause.
     - **Complement Clauses** (complete the meaning of a verb):
       - *He is sure **that Hari will walk in soon**.* → *"that Hari will walk in soon"* is a complement clause.
     - **Adverbial Clauses** (modify verbs/adjectives/adverbs):
       - *Anuradha is leaving **after she has had her dinner**.* → *"after she has had her dinner"* is an adverbial clause (adjunct).

#### **B. Voice (Active/Passive)**
   - **Active → Passive Conversion**:
     - *The banker counted the money.* (Active) → *The money **was counted by the banker**.* (Passive).
     - *You are easily scared by loud noises.* → *Loud noises easily scare you.*
   - **Rules**:
     - Subject of active voice becomes the **object** in passive.
     - Verb changes to **be + past participle** (e.g., *is counted*, *was destroyed*).

#### **C. Mood & Modality**
   - **Indicative Mood** (statements/facts):
     - *Ajay won the championship.* → **Indicative**.
   - **Subjunctive Mood** (hypotheticals/wishes):
     - *If I **were** you, I would apologize.* (Not tested here but good to know).
   - **Modal Verbs** (possibility, suggestion, obligation):
     - *Zain **could** be in a cranky mood.* → **Weak possibility**.
     - *She informed them she **would** be late.* → **Future in the past**.
     - ***Shall** we make a move?* → **Polite suggestion**.

#### **D. Tenses**
   - **Past Progressive**:
     - *Bilal **was visiting** Lucknow after a decade.* → Action in progress in the past.
   - **Present Perfect Continuous**:
     - *There **has been** an increase in enrollment.* → Action started in the past, continues to present.
   - **Interrogative Forms**:
     - *You closed the door.* → *Did you close the door?* (Simple past → **did + subject + base verb**).

#### **E. Question Tags**
   - *She destroyed the whole system, **didn’t she**?*
     - Rule: **Auxiliary verb + subject pronoun** (negative for positive statements).

---

### **3. Vocabulary & Semantics**
#### **A. Word Meanings**
   - **Faux pas** → Inappropriate behavior.
   - **Modus operandi** → Method of action.
   - **Snug** → Comfortable.
   - **Ascertainable** → Determinable.

#### **B. Syllables & Stress**
   - **Syllable Counting**:
     - *Substantially* → **4 syllables** (sub-stan-tial-ly).
     - *Utterance* → **3 syllables** (ut-ter-ance).
   - **Stress Patterns**:
     - *Midnight* → **MID-night** (1st syllable).
     - *Suppressed* → su-**PRESSED** (2nd syllable).

#### **C. Punctuation & Pauses (Prosody)**
   - **Sentence Pauses** (for speech/reading aloud):
     - Example:
       - *Long years ago / we made a tryst with destiny // and now the time comes / when we shall redeem our pledge...*
       - **//** = longer pause, **/** = shorter pause.

---

### **4. Communication & Pragmatics**
#### **A. Polite Requests**
   - **Direct vs. Indirect**:
     - ❌ *Give me those reports.* (Rude).
     - ✅ *Could you please give me those reports?* (Polite).

#### **B. Intonation & Meaning**
   - *They won the **match**.* (Stress on *match* → **raising a question** or emphasizing surprise).

#### **C. Formal vs. Informal Language**
   - **Formal**: *I was consulting with him **whether** to consider their proposal.* (Not *"if"* in formal contexts).

---

### **5. Literary & Figurative Language**
   - **Metaphors**:
     - *The match results **lifted the spirits** of fans.* → **Made fans cheerful** (not literal lifting).
   - **Irony/Understatement**:
     - *Bartleby’s lack of biography is an **irreparable loss to literature**.* → **Hyperbole** (exaggeration for effect).

---

### **6. Error Identification**
   - **Odd One Out**:
     - *Which, who, that, **are*** → **"Are"** is a verb; others are relative pronouns.
   - **Incorrect Usage**:
     - *He drove the ambulance **fastly** despite busy traffic.* → **"Fast"** (adverb), not *"fastly"*.

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. Reading Comprehension & Vocabulary**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Reading Comprehension] --> B[Main Idea]
    A --> C[Tone & Purpose]
    A --> D[Inference]
    A --> E[Vocabulary in Context]
    E --> F[Synonyms/Antonyms]
    E --> G[Word Stress & Syllables]
    D --> H[Implicit Meaning]
    C --> I[Narrator's Perspective]
```

### **2. Grammar & Syntax**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Grammar] --> B[Sentence Structure]
    B --> B1[Simple/Compound/Complex]
    B --> B2[Clauses]
    B2 --> B2a[Relative/Adjectival]
    B2 --> B2b[Complement]
    B2 --> B2c[Adverbial]
    A --> C[Voice]
    C --> C1[Active-Passive Conversion]
    A --> D[Tenses]
    D --> D1[Past Progressive]
    D --> D2[Present Perfect Continuous]
    A --> E[Modals]
    E --> E1[Possibility: could/might]
    E --> E2[Polite Suggestions: shall]
    A --> F[Question Tags]
```

### **3. Communication & Pragmatics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Communication] --> B[Politeness]
    B --> B1[Direct vs. Indirect Requests]
    A --> C[Intonation]
    C --> C1[Stress & Meaning]
    A --> D[Formal vs. Informal]
    D --> D1[Word Choice: whether/if]
    A --> E[Prosody]
    E --> E1[Pauses in Speech]
```

### **4. Literary Devices & Figurative Language**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Literary Devices] --> B[Metaphor]
    A --> C[Irony/Hyperbole]
    A --> D[Understatement]
    B --> B1[Non-literal Meanings]
    C --> C1[Exaggeration for Effect]
```

### **5. Error Identification**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Error Identification] --> B[Odd One Out]
    A --> C[Incorrect Word Forms]
    C --> C1[Fast vs. Fastly]
    A --> D[Misplaced Modifiers]
    A --> E[Subject-Verb Agreement]
```

---
## **Key Takeaways for Exam Preparation**
1. **Reading Comprehension**:
   - Practice **summarizing passages** and identifying **tone/purpose**.
   - Focus on **vocabulary in context** (synonyms/antonyms).
   - Listen for **stress patterns** in audio-based questions.

2. **Grammar**:
   - Master **active-passive conversions**.
   - Learn **clause types** (relative, complement, adverbial).
   - Review **tenses** (past progressive, present perfect continuous).
   - Understand **modals** for possibility, suggestion, and obligation.

3. **Communication**:
   - Use **polite language** in requests.
   - Recognize **intonation shifts** for meaning.
   - Practice **prosody** (pauses in speech).

4. **Vocabulary**:
   - Memorize **common literary terms** (*faux pas*, *modus operandi*).
   - Count **syllables** and identify **stressed syllables**.

5. **Literary Devices**:
   - Identify **metaphors**, **irony**, and **hyperbole** in passages.

6. **Error Spotting**:
   - Watch for **misused words** (*fastly* → *fast*).
   - Identify **odd-one-out** in word lists.

---
**Final Tip**: For audio-based questions, **practice listening to English speeches** (e.g., famous speeches like *Tryst with Destiny*) to familiarize yourself with **stress, intonation, and pauses**.
